column5: Itasca State Park founded this day in 1891 is Minnesota’s oldest state park and the second oldest state park in the country second only to New York’s Niagara Falls State Park. The park is the headwaters of the Mississippi River and was named the the explorer Henry Schoolcraft by from the Latin “veritas caput” meaning “true head.” Minnesota DNR - Itasca State Park Established in 1891 Itasca is Minnesota's oldest state park. Today the park totals more than 32000 acres and includes more than 100 lakes. Walk across the mighty Mississippi as it starts its winding journey 2552 miles to the Gulf of Mexico. Stand under towering pines and visit landmarks of centuries gone by throughout the park. Camp under the stars or stay the night in one of our 45 overnight units. Explore Wilderness Drive past the 2000-acre Wilderness Sanctuary one of Minnesota's seven National Natural Landmarks. Wildlife. The diversity of vegetation in the park supports many wildlife species. Birding is excellent and visitors are encouraged to help spot and record the bird life they see in the park. Some birds you can expect to see include loons grebes cormorants herons ducks owls hummingbirds woodpeckers chickadees nuthatches kinglets vireos tanagers finches and warblers. Trails in the park are shared with deer chipmunks and squirrels. Beaver porcupine black bears and wolves also reside in the park.
